p: A particular concern has been the rise in acute food insecurity. In April 2020, the Head of the World Food Program David Beasley warned that unless rapid mitigation measures are undertaken, the world may face “multiple famines of biblical proportions,” potentially doubling the number of people at risk of dying of acute hunger from 135 million to 265 million people by the end of 2020.1 By November 2020, the WFP (2020a) revised these numbers upwards, estimating that a total number of 271.8 million people are facing acute food insecurity due to exacerbating effects of the pandemic alongside other compounding factors.
